course_title: Urban Development and Design Research: Thesis

learning_outcomes.description: Critically analyse a body of literature or creative works.
Distinguish a research problem in the literature or creative works.
Design an investigatory strategy to address an identified research problem.
Apply an investigatory strategy to an identified research problem.
Construct a scholarly thesis based on argument, evidence and insight.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale: 

The purpose of this assignment is to demonstrate the research processes undertaken to date, and to confirm the plan and format for the completed thesis document. Submit a research report consisting of a) a detailed Research Proposal, b) a short Essay suitable to be incorporated in the thesis, and c) an annotated bibliography.

Format the Research Proposal under the following headings: Title / Abstract (100-300 words) / Discussion (a prose statement of up to 600-1200 words describing the subject of the research, the method or mode of inquiry, the likely significance of the study / Chapter Plan (one-two pages only, 3-5 bullet points per chapter) / Research Plan (showing work week by week to submission / Bibliography of works relevant to the study (mark with a star those works consulted thus far.)

Essay: a sample of writing showing your ability to report and/or analyse the first stages of the research. This could be a draft of a chapter, a set of precis of readings at length, an exegesis of a construction, experiment or field trip, as agreed with the advisor. (suggested length 1200-1500 words)

Provision is made for progressive assessment; formative by the supervisor in weekly meetings, and summative in marks and feedback for this assignment.

The work is due digitally by 2pm on the day of submission, and presented at a seminar later that day, scheduled between 2pm-5pm (Room TBC). Seminar presentations should no more than three slides and run no longer than 10 mins  in order to allow time for feedback.

Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale: 

The Thesis is a document of 10,000-15,000 words including footnotes. The word count could be less if the research outcomes are largely graphical or numerical, as agreed with the advisor. Apart from text, the Thesis may contain drawings, data, models, images, video and other media as agreed with the Advisor.

The Thesis may develop research previously conducted for other 2 Unit Part D Research Courses. However, the expectation is that prior work has been reconsidered and reframed in the Thesis; it should not be reproduced verbatim. The Thesis should represent a substantial new body of work. No more than 20% of the text can be repeated from earlier submissions. The Thesis should contain a statement headed “Prior research included in this Thesis” identifying any sections that draw on research conducted prior to enrolling in UDAD7061 and any prose sections that have been previously submitted for a previous course.

The Thesis should be presented as a PDF document suitable to be printed at A4 either portrait or landscape format, or A3 landscape format. If the Thesis includes video or 3D models embedded in the PDF, make sure to also include 2D still images of this material in case of future media incompatibility.

Formative Feedback: You should be meeting and discussing drafts regularly with your advisor(s) during teaching weeks. Formal formative feedback points are scheduled in Week 9 of Semester 2 2024 when a draft chapter should be submitted directly to your advisor for feedback. Presentations are scheduled during Week 6 in Semester 1 2025 (Time and date to be confirmed following the release of the Semester 1 2025 timetable). Students will present a 10-15 minute paper based on one aspect of their research and include a brief overview of how this fits into the thesis. Formative feedback will be given verbally following presentations. Please refer to the Course Schedule for the Zoom Link.

Following the examination of the Thesis, students will be required to make any recommended corrections or amendments to the satisfaction of the Advisor and Course Coordinator, and upload the corrected Thesis to eSpace.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment Rationale: 

Following the assessment of the Thesis, 10% of the awarded grade will be withheld, pending:

a) the satisfactory completion of any corrections and amendments recommended as part of the examination,

b) If the student chooses to publish the thesis through UQ's eSpace research repository, then filling out the permissions form. 

Students should include a table that succinctly demonstrates how they have responded to any feedback, recommendations and corrections made by the examiners.

Satisfactory corrections, amendments and upload will be completed to the satisfaction of the supervisor and course co-ordinator.
